    7667             : /* ----------
    7668             :  * convert_value_to_string          Convert a non-null Datum to C string
    7669             :  *
    7670             :  * Note: the result is in the estate's eval_mcontext, and will be cleared
    7671             :  * by the next exec_eval_cleanup() call.  The invoked output function might
    7672             :  * leave additional cruft there as well, so just pfree'ing the result string
    7673             :  * would not be enough to avoid memory leaks if we did not do it like this.
    7674             :  * In most usages the Datum being passed in is also in that context (if
    7675             :  * pass-by-reference) and so an exec_eval_cleanup() call is needed anyway.
    7676             :  *
    7677             :  * Note: not caching the conversion function lookup is bad for performance.
    7678             :  * However, this function isn't currently used in any places where an extra
    7679             :  * catalog lookup or two seems like a big deal.
    7680             :  * ----------
    7681             :  */

    7698             : /* ----------
    7699             :  * exec_cast_value          Cast a value if required
    7700             :  *
    7701             :  * Note that *isnull is an input and also an output parameter.  While it's
    7702             :  * unlikely that a cast operation would produce null from non-null or vice
    7703             :  * versa, that could happen in principle.
    7704             :  *
    7705             :  * Note: the estate's eval_mcontext is used for temporary storage, and may
    7706             :  * also contain the result Datum if we have to do a conversion to a pass-

    7769             : /* ----------
    7770             :  * get_cast_hashentry           Look up how to perform a type cast
    7771             :  *
    7772             :  * Returns a plpgsql_CastHashEntry if an expression has to be evaluated,
    7773             :  * or NULL if the cast is a mere no-op relabeling.  If there's work to be
    7774             :  * done, the cast_exprstate field contains an expression evaluation tree
    7775             :  * based on a CaseTestExpr input, and the cast_in_use field should be set
    7776             :  * true while executing it.

    7855             : 
    7856             :         /*
    7857             :          * Apply coercion.  We use the special coercion context
    7858             :          * COERCION_PLPGSQL to match plpgsql's historical behavior, namely
    7859             :          * that any cast not available at ASSIGNMENT level will be implemented
    7860             :          * as an I/O coercion.  (It's somewhat dubious that we prefer I/O
    7861             :          * coercion over cast pathways that exist at EXPLICIT level.  Changing
    7862             :          * that would cause assorted minor behavioral differences though, and
    7863             :          * a user who wants the explicit-cast behavior can always write an
    7864             :          * explicit cast.)
    7865             :          *
    7866             :          * If source type is UNKNOWN, coerce_to_target_type will fail (it only
    7867             :          * expects to see that for Const input nodes), so don't call it; we'll
    7868             :          * apply CoerceViaIO instead.  Likewise, it doesn't currently work for
    7869             :          * coercing RECORD to some other type, so skip for that too.
    7870             :          */

    7875             :                                               (Node *) placeholder, srctype,

    7879             :                                               -1);
    7880             : 
    7881             :         /*
    7882             :          * If there's no cast path according to the parser, fall back to using
    7883             :          * an I/O coercion; this is semantically dubious but matches plpgsql's
    7884             :          * historical behavior.  We would need something of the sort for
    7885             :          * UNKNOWN literals in any case.  (This is probably now only reachable
    7886             :          * in the case where srctype is UNKNOWN/RECORD.)
    7887             :          */

    7917             :

    7921             :

    7923         338 :         cast_entry->cast_exprstate = NULL;

    7926             :

    7931        3242 :     if (expr_entry->cast_expr == NULL)
    7932           0 :         return NULL;
    7933             : 
    7934             :     /*
    7935             :      * Prepare the expression for execution, if it's not been done already in
    7936             :      * the current transaction; also, if it's marked busy in the current
    7937             :      * transaction, abandon that expression tree and build a new one, so as to
    7938             :      * avoid potential problems with recursive cast expressions and failed
    7939             :      * executions.  (We will leak some memory intra-transaction if that
    7940             :      * happens a lot, but we don't expect it to.)  It's okay to update the
    7941             :      * hash table with the new tree because all plpgsql functions within a
    7942             :      * given transaction share the same simple_eval_estate.  (Well, regular
    7943             :      * functions do; DO blocks have private simple_eval_estates, and private
    7944             :      * cast hash tables to go with them.)
    7945             :      */
    7946        3242 :     curlxid = MyProc->lxid;
    7947        3242 :     if (cast_entry->cast_lxid != curlxid || cast_entry->cast_in_use)
    7948             :     {
    7949         694 :         oldcontext = MemoryContextSwitchTo(estate->simple_eval_estate->es_query_cxt);
    7950         694 :         cast_entry->cast_exprstate = ExecInitExpr(expr_entry->cast_expr, NULL);
    7951         694 :         cast_entry->cast_in_use = false;
    7952         694 :         cast_entry->cast_lxid = curlxid;
    7953         694 :         MemoryContextSwitchTo(oldcontext);
    7954             :     }
    7955             : 
    7956        3242 :     return cast_entry;
    7957             : }
    7958             : 
    7959             : 
    7960             : /* ----------
    7961             :  * exec_simple_check_plan -     Check if a plan is simple enough to
    7962             :  *                              be evaluated by ExecEvalExpr() instead
    7963             :  *                              of SPI.
    7964             :  *
    7965             :  * Note: the refcount manipulations in this function assume that expr->plan
    7966             :  * is a "saved" SPI plan.  That's a bit annoying from the caller's standpoint,
    7967             :  * but it's otherwise difficult to avoid leaking the plan on failure.
    7968             :  * ----------
    7969             :  */
    7970             : static void
    7971       24164 : exec_simple_check_plan(PLpgSQL_execstate *estate, PLpgSQL_expr *expr)
    7972             : {
    7973             :     List       *plansources;

    7977             :     MemoryContext oldcontext;
    7978             : 
    7979             :     /*
    7980             :      * Initialize to "not simple".
    7981             :      */

    7983       24164 :     expr->expr_rw_param = NULL;
    7984             : 
    7985             :     /*
    7986             :      * Check the analyzed-and-rewritten form of the query to see if we will be
    7987             :      * able to treat it as a simple expression.  Since this function is only
    7988             :      * called immediately after creating the CachedPlanSource, we need not
    7989             :      * worry about the query being stale.
    7990             :      */
    7991             :

    7993             :      * We can only test queries that resulted in exactly one CachedPlanSource

    8086             : /*

    8162       25158 :     expr->expr_simple_mutable = contain_mutable_functions((Node *) tle_expr);
    8163             : 
    8164             :     /*
    8165             :      * Lastly, check to see if there's a possibility of optimizing a
    8166             :      * read/write parameter.
    8167             :      */
    8168       25158 :     exec_check_rw_parameter(expr);
    8169       25158 : }
    8170             : 
    8171             : /*
    8172             :  * exec_check_rw_parameter --- can we pass expanded object as read/write param?
    8173             :  *
    8174             :  * If we have an assignment like "x := array_append(x, foo)" in which the
    8175             :  * top-level function is trusted not to corrupt its argument in case of an
    8176             :  * error, then when x has an expanded object as value, it is safe to pass the
    8177             :  * value as a read/write pointer and let the function modify the value
    8178             :  * in-place.
    8179             :  *
    8180             :  * This function checks for a safe expression, and sets expr->expr_rw_param
    8181             :  * to the address of any Param within the expression that can be passed as
    8182             :  * read/write (there can be only one); or to NULL when there is no safe Param.
    8183             :  *
    8184             :  * Note that this mechanism intentionally applies the safety labeling to just
    8185             :  * one Param; the expression could contain other Params referencing the target
    8186             :  * variable, but those must still be treated as read-only.
    8187             :  *
    8188             :  * Also note that we only apply this optimization within simple expressions.
    8189             :  * There's no point in it for non-simple expressions, because the
    8190             :  * exec_run_select code path will flatten any expanded result anyway.
    8191             :  * Also, it's safe to assume that an expr_simple_expr tree won't get copied
    8192             :  * somewhere before it gets compiled, so that looking for pointer equality
    8193             :  * to expr_rw_param will work for matching the target Param.  That'd be much
    8194             :  * shakier in the general case.
    8195             :  */
    8196             : static void
    8197       25158 : exec_check_rw_parameter(PLpgSQL_expr *expr)
    8198             : {
    8199             :     int         target_dno;
    8200             :     Oid         funcid;
    8201             :     List       *fargs;
    8202             :     ListCell   *lc;
    8203             : 
    8204             :     /* Assume unsafe */
    8205       25158 :     expr->expr_rw_param = NULL;
    8206             : 
    8207             :     /* Done if expression isn't an assignment source */
    8208       25158 :     target_dno = expr->target_param;
    8209       25158 :     if (target_dno < 0)
    8210       20692 :         return;
    8211             : 
    8212             :     /*
    8213             :      * If target variable isn't referenced by expression, no need to look
    8214             :      * further.
    8215             :      */
    8216        4466 :     if (!bms_is_member(target_dno, expr->paramnos))
    8217         670 :         return;
    8218             : 
    8219             :     /* Shouldn't be here for non-simple expression */
    8220        3796 :     Assert(expr->expr_simple_expr != NULL);
    8221             : 
    8222             :     /*
    8223             :      * Top level of expression must be a simple FuncExpr, OpExpr, or

    8229             :

    8246             :             F_ARRAY_SUBSCRIPT_HANDLER)

    8253             :

    8255          58 :                 param->paramid == target_dno + 1)
    8256             :             {
    8257             :                 /* Found the Param we want to pass as read/write */
    8258          52 :                 expr->expr_rw_param = param;
    8259          52 :                 return;
    8260             :             }
    8261             :         }
    8262             : 
    8263           6 :         return;
    8264             :     }
    8265             :     else
    8266        1696 :         return;
    8267             : 
    8268             :     /*
    8269             :      * The top-level function must be one that we trust to be "safe".

    8272             :      */
    8273        2040 :     if (!(funcid == F_ARRAY_APPEND ||
    8274             :           funcid == F_ARRAY_PREPEND))
    8275        1968 :         return;
    8276             : 
    8277             :     /*
    8278             :      * The target variable (in the form of a Param) must appear as a direct
    8279             :      * argument of the top-level function.  References further down in the
    8280             :      * tree can't be optimized; but on the other hand, they don't invalidate
    8281             :      * optimizing the top-level call, since that will be executed last.
    8282             :      */
    8283          96 :     foreach(lc, fargs)
    8284             :     {
    8285          84 :         Node       *arg = (Node *) lfirst(lc);
    8286             :

    8352             : /*
    8353             :  * plpgsql_create_econtext --- create an eval_econtext for the current function
    8354             :  *
    8355             :  * We may need to create a new shared_simple_eval_estate too, if there's not
    8356             :  * one already for the current transaction.  The EState will be cleaned up at
    8357             :  * transaction end.  Ditto for shared_simple_eval_resowner.
    8358             :  */
    8359             : static void
    8360       98030 : plpgsql_create_econtext(PLpgSQL_execstate *estate)
    8361             : {
    8362             :     SimpleEcontextStackEntry *entry;
    8363             : 
    8364             :     /*
    8365             :      * Create an EState for evaluation of simple expressions, if there's not
    8366             :      * one already in the current transaction.  The EState is made a child of
    8367             :      * TopTransactionContext so it will have the right lifespan.
    8368             :      *
    8369             :      * Note that this path is never taken when beginning a DO block; the
    8370             :      * required EState was already made by plpgsql_inline_handler.  However,
    8371             :      * if the DO block executes COMMIT or ROLLBACK, then we'll come here and
    8372             :      * make a shared EState to use for the rest of the DO block.  That's OK;
    8373             :      * see the comments for shared_simple_eval_estate.  (Note also that a DO
    8374             :      * block will continue to use its private cast hash table for the rest of
    8375             :      * the block.  That's okay for now, but it might cause problems someday.)
    8376             :      */
    8377       98030 :     if (estate->simple_eval_estate == NULL)
    8378             :     {
    8379             :         MemoryContext oldcontext;
    8380             : 
    8381       15516 :         if (shared_simple_eval_estate == NULL)
    8382             :         {
    8383       15508 :             oldcontext = MemoryContextSwitchTo(TopTransactionContext);
    8384       15508 :             shared_simple_eval_estate = CreateExecutorState();
    8385       15508 :             MemoryContextSwitchTo(oldcontext);
    8386             :         }
    8387       15516 :         estate->simple_eval_estate = shared_simple_eval_estate;
    8388             :     }
    8389             : 
    8390             :     /*
    8391             :      * Likewise for the simple-expression resource owner.
    8392             :      */
    8393       98030 :     if (estate->simple_eval_resowner == NULL)

    8401             :

    8405       98030 :     estate->eval_econtext = CreateExprContext(estate->simple_eval_estate);

    8422             : /*
    8423             :  * plpgsql_destroy_econtext --- destroy function's econtext

    8444             : /*
    8445             :  * plpgsql_xact_cb --- post-transaction-commit-or-abort cleanup
    8446             :  *
    8447             :  * If a simple-expression EState was created in the current transaction,
    8448             :  * it has to be cleaned up.  The same for the simple-expression resowner.
    8449             :  */
    8450             : void
    8451      260948 : plpgsql_xact_cb(XactEvent event, void *arg)
    8452             : {
    8453             :     /*
    8454             :      * If we are doing a clean transaction shutdown, free the EState and tell
    8455             :      * the resowner to release whatever plancache references it has, so that
    8456             :      * all remaining resources will be released correctly.  (We don't need to
    8457             :      * actually delete the resowner here; deletion of the
    8458             :      * TopTransactionResourceOwner will take care of that.)
    8459             :      *
    8460             :      * In an abort, we expect the regular abort recovery procedures to release
    8461             :      * everything of interest, so just clear our pointers.
    8462             :      */
    8463      260948 :     if (event == XACT_EVENT_COMMIT ||
    8464      136318 :         event == XACT_EVENT_PARALLEL_COMMIT ||

    8512             : /*
    8513             :  * assign_simple_var --- assign a new value to any VAR datum.
    8514             :  *
    8515             :  * This should be the only mechanism for assignment to simple variables,
    8516             :  * lest we do the release of the old value incorrectly (not to mention
    8517             :  * the detoasting business).
    8518             :  */
    8519             : static void
    8520      433952 : assign_simple_var(PLpgSQL_execstate *estate, PLpgSQL_var *var,
    8521             :                   Datum newvalue, bool isnull, bool freeable)
    8522             : {
    8523      433952 :     Assert(var->dtype == PLPGSQL_DTYPE_VAR ||
    8524             :            var->dtype == PLPGSQL_DTYPE_PROMISE);
    8525             : 
    8526             :     /*
    8527             :      * In non-atomic contexts, we do not want to store TOAST pointers in
    8528             :      * variables, because such pointers might become stale after a commit.
    8529             :      * Forcibly detoast in such cases.  We don't want to detoast (flatten)
    8530             :      * expanded objects, however; those should be OK across a transaction
    8531             :      * boundary since they're just memory-resident objects.  (Elsewhere in
    8532             :      * this module, operations on expanded records likewise need to request
    8533             :      * detoasting of record fields when !estate->atomic.  Expanded arrays are
    8534             :      * not a problem since all array entries are always detoasted.)
    8535             :      */
    8536      433952 :     if (!estate->atomic && !isnull && var->datatype->typlen == -1 &&
    8537       43538 :         VARATT_IS_EXTERNAL_NON_EXPANDED(DatumGetPointer(newvalue)))
    8538             :     {
    8539             :         MemoryContext oldcxt;
    8540             :         Datum       detoasted;
    8541             : 
    8542             :         /*
    8543             :          * Do the detoasting in the eval_mcontext to avoid long-term leakage
    8544             :          * of whatever memory toast fetching might leak.  Then we have to copy
    8545             :          * the detoasted datum to the function's main context, which is a
    8546             :          * pain, but there's little choice.
    8547             :          */
    8548          16 :         oldcxt = MemoryContextSwitchTo(get_eval_mcontext(estate));
    8549          16 :         detoasted = PointerGetDatum(detoast_external_attr((struct varlena *) DatumGetPointer(newvalue)));
    8550          16 :         MemoryContextSwitchTo(oldcxt);
    8551             :         /* Now's a good time to not leak the input value if it's freeable */
    8552          16 :         if (freeable)
    8553          16 :             pfree(DatumGetPointer(newvalue));
    8554             :         /* Once we copy the value, it's definitely freeable */
    8555          16 :         newvalue = datumCopy(detoasted, false, -1);
    8556          16 :         freeable = true;
    8557             :         /* Can't clean up eval_mcontext here, but it'll happen before long */
    8558             :     }
    8559             : 
    8560             :     /* Free the old value if needed */
    8561      433952 :     if (var->freeval)
    8562             :     {
    8563       73772 :         if (DatumIsReadWriteExpandedObject(var->value,
    8564             :                                            var->isnull,
    8565             :                                            var->datatype->typlen))
    8566        6960 :             DeleteExpandedObject(var->value);
    8567             :         else
    8568       66812 :             pfree(DatumGetPointer(var->value));
    8569             :     }
    8570             :     /* Assign new value to datum */
    8571      433952 :     var->value = newvalue;
    8572      433952 :     var->isnull = isnull;
    8573      433952 :     var->freeval = freeable;
    8574             : 
    8575             :     /*
    8576             :      * If it's a promise variable, then either we just assigned the promised
    8577             :      * value, or the user explicitly assigned an overriding value.  Either
    8578             :      * way, cancel the promise.
    8579             :      */
    8580      433952 :     var->promise = PLPGSQL_PROMISE_NONE;
    8581      433952 : }

    8613             :  * exec_eval_using_params --- evaluate params of USING clause

    8692             : /*
    8693             :  * Open portal for dynamic query
    8694             :  *
    8695             :  * Caution: this resets the stmt_mcontext at exit.  We might eventually need
